cons: I worked at Jefferson Health Methodist's operating room, and the culture is very toxic. The perioperative clinical educator gaslights you if you don't "meet perfection" and doesn't strictly outline the guidelines or resources to succeed. The preceptors do not effectively communicate with the clinical educator and creates an atmosphere of "you don't know anything, just watch" and belittles your current and past knowledge. This culture of the "newbie is dumb and unacceptable" is also worsened by the fact that asking questions to the preceptors just negatively affects your image.

review_title: Great for a new grad but otherwise avoid
job_title: Family Nurse Practitioner/Emergency Services in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Not many here. Good PTO (33 days/year, or 10 hours every pay perio) but good luck finding time to take off and use the PTO as they stack your shifts if you request time off. Health benefits seem pretty good. Good co-workers in the NP/PA realm in the emergency department minus the management team
cons: Very erratic hours for scheduling, shifts are either 6,8,9,10, or 12 hours. If employed in the emergency department you HAVE to work in the observation unit, fast track, main ED (only the days the ED residents are not there), at four outside urgent care centers (no reimbursement for travel), and tele-triage (so the hospital can bill patient if they decide to leave after they have been triaged and seen by someone on a video screen). Rarely is the schedule posted more than a month beforehand. Very rarely do you get more than 2 days off in a row in any month unless you request for time off. Poor response from management to inquiries. No professional growth opportunities or training provided by the emergency department leadership. No diversity in leadership of the emergency department and unresponsive to feedback. No feedback given to you about your work performance. No rewards, incentives, or praise to see /for seeing patients faster. Pay is less than most other establishments in the area. One of the biggest cons is that you are not trained on procedures here and if anything interesting does come up is always goes to the residents to perform.

pros:
good coworkers (the ones who are still left)
level 1 trauma center with plenty of trauma
charge nurses who care
cons:
Jefferson used to be an ok place to work for RNs; but in the last decade, they've been living off their legacy vs current reality. 
Jefferson nurses are known for being the lowest paid hospital in Center City. 
During the pandemic, they took away all 403b (401k) employer matching, didn't offer any COVID bonuses, and gave no raises. 
As we progressively lose a substantial number of nurses due to better compensation & working conditions/nursing care elsewhere, the staff are now being hit with nowhere to park in an increasingly unsafe area of the city. Parking is minimally $30/day at center city garages, and nurses are not allowed to park at the adjoining garage to the hospital. 
Management is unreceptive & administration is out of touch.

pros:
Kind staff (for the most part).
PTO
Stable hours
No on call 
No severe punishments for calling out
cons: I worked at one of the NJ campuses. Having 6 patients for one nurse with one or two technicians on the floor was the norm. We were spread thin prior to Covid, and afterwards it had gotten so much worse. Patient assignments did not take acuity into consideration. Management had this ideal depiction of how to care for patients but never stepped in to help. No appreciation for nurses and all of the BS we went through. Night shift physicians/NPs spread thin, and take it out on nurses. We were also forced to travel to different campuses to meet staffing requirements (sometimes without notice). We were put in a lot of situations that could have cost us our licenses. Applied to different units, but never offered a chance to even interview. No help from HR whatsoever. Some nurses reprimanded for small things, but other terrible nurses are overlooked. A lot of people have quit, and they are refusing to hire more nurses to fill in the gaps. Now they are asking nurses to pick up shifts. Overall, morale is low and most nurses want to leave.

review_title: Competent and Compassionate Staff that is Poorly Appreciated by Managers
pros: TJUH is an excellent tertiary care center located in Philadelphia.  We are able to treat patients within the city with minor complaints as well as complex patients transferred in from regional health centers.  I truly trust the physicians, nurses, and technicians of Jeff.  They are responsive, empathetic, and skilled people with whom I am proud to work.
cons: Communication and respect of the staff are two large areas where Jeff is lacking.  There is a gulf that exists between management and the nursing staff as well as between management and the house staff.  It is distressing to watch how often the most talented people we have at Jeff are the last ones management will go to for advice for improvements.  The process of making suggestions for improvements or complaints about the deficiencies is so arduous that it is prohibitive.

review_title: Too Corporate for their own good!
job_title: Staff Technical Support Engineer in Philadelphia, PA

cons: Worked at Jefferson for 25 years and saw quite a few different Senior administrations come and go. Tom Lewis was the best President this hospital ever had. They are too busy buying up all the real estate around the campus and not supporting the employees needs. I truly thought that I would retire from here but I could not stay any longer to see where this hospital is heading to. This used to be a true Jefferson family but now it seems to be about greed. Nurses are over worked and truly understaffed. I am not a disgruntled employee as I stated that i resigned from my position.  All other Hospitals in the area pay much better than Jefferson and this is always the way its been the case.

review_title: One Big Family and Level 1 Trauma Center Patient Exposure
job_title: Critical Care RN in Phila, PA
pros: Assessment and clinical judgement respected, encouraged and embraced by all members of team including Attending Physicians. Being assertive and a fierce patient advocate there is a lot of autonomy if your clinical judgement and educational background supports your questions and concerns as an equal team member. I also receive ICU Patients across all units so always learning something new in my practice.
cons: You have to flip flop between days and nightshifts sometimes right after each other and you put in your "schedule" but it is always edited to where you have to arrange swaps with coworkers to avoid calling out. Also strict policy on sick call outs and increasing amount of EPIC documentation is cumbersome and takes time away from hands on patient care.

review_title: Impossible to get things done due to poor leadership
job_title: Linux Systems Administrator in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
- Location; great area downtown and convenient to public transit
- Significant amount of "ETO" (PTO); however if you leave you are only paid out as much unused "ETO" time as you gave notice. If you have 3-4+ weeks unused PTO, but only give two weeks notice, you only get two weeks of ETO paid back. It's not really "earned"after all.
cons:
- Bureaucracy; single 20-second tasks in the IT department ("IS&T") can take days, weeks, or months of multiple tickets being opened, dozens of e-mails, and meetings without really getting any where because....
- Management; they really have no clue what they are managing. I had never worked somewhere that the managers had literally no clue what their employees did and had never done the job themselves. So-called "leaders" are placed into positions of power without having any real inkling of what their "direct-reports" actually do.
- Work/life balance; you are sort of just expected to jump on telephone calls and conference "bridges" at a moment's notice at 2:00 AM when something is inevitably broken due to poor planning

review_title: No major complaints for a major corporate environment.
pros:
Location in Center City is great, near many cool places.
Upper management really seems to care about continuously improving and making it a better place for both patients and employees.
The typical range of folks, but on the whole it's really a great bunch of coworkers.  Only a small handful I really didn't like.  In a department of over a hundred, I'd say that's pretty darn good.
Nice and stable work environment.
cons:
It's a huge corporation, so you get some of the typical expected BS.
It is in Center City and for the most part it's safe, but you don't often go to work in the burbs to hear about the murder on the street in front of your building from the night before.
Interaction between hospital IS and university IT is sometimes cooperative but often adversarial.

review_title: Strong top 100 Hospital that is growing
job_title: Operating Room Assistant in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
Great pay under the hospital & union collective bargaining agreement. Benefits are excellent and work conditions are good. The union will pay/reimburse members for any personal/professional development they seek. Jefferson makes education widely available to employees via many avenues; seminars, conferences and subsidized classes with "Jeff @ nite". 

They even have a shark tank like program where the hospital will assist employees in patenting their ideas. Great organization.
cons: Not many. You are at the mercy of the state of relations between the union and hospital administration(currently good) or even some department heads. It's a people business like any organization with humans running it. So my cons would be limited to those individuals who either mis-step or abuse trust from senior leadership.

review_title: I believe that Jefferson means well but I don't think there's enough emphasis on nurses
pros: Magnet certification, up to date on latest research/nursing policies & procedures.
cons: I don't think nurses are paid nearly enough. I can't speak for other departments as far as salary but nurses are the backbone of the entire institution and I don't feel appreciated as a nurse at jefferson. I think the new president is spending way too much money on trying to monopolize Jefferson and buying up every hospital in the area rather than focusing on it's employees. Happy employees lead to happy patients. It's a simple concept. Also I think the health insurance is lousy and I pay for the highest/most premium package.

pros: Good health benefits, job stability, friendly co-workers.
cons: Poor pay. Haven't received anything other than a 2 percent yearly increase in 7 years. Salary was competitive when I started years ago, but now I am below the 25th percentile nationally for my job and experience level. The times I've asked for substantial pay increases, I'm always told that it is impossible, not because of my performance, but because of the budget. My salary never increases, but responsibilities and requirements are increasing by the day!

review_title: Culture of cooperative commitment to excellence in patient care.

review_title: I was proud to be hired to work here, I only wish they treated their employee's as well as they treat their patients.

review_title: Great benefits, but new policies making employees unhappy

cons: New policy for non-union employees cut allowable absences and latenesses drastically, creating a lot of anxiety for those with chronic health conditions, children, relatives to caregive for, etc. Discipline structure allows for little wiggle room and makes it easier for employees to be terminated. Aside from this, some direct management members can be unapproachable.

review_title: It was a great career opportunity at one time, but no more.

review_title: Jefferson is a great hospital,  but below average treatment is given to it personnel.
pros: We give great health care to our patients.  The staff generally feels that it is all in the same boat, and working for the same goal.   We work very hard, but we are a fairly close knit group.   Vacation and times off is generally granted.   Working in the city is great,  lots of things to do at lunch time and after hours.  The campus has a few green areas to take breaks in, and is close to bigger parks and Independence Hall.  Tom Lewis returns calls to whomever calls him,  how many CEO's do that?  Being in Center City, great public transportation access.
cons: Management is promoted solely on how they are related to others in the department,  not on the skills and knowledge they have in the field.  Too much politics and bean counting,  not enough actual work done by management.   They seem to think the signs of great health care is how many patients go through the doors,  not how many patients are getting great health care(the actual Doc's and Nurses, and other professionals don't work this way, hence the great health care).  Management swears by their "Open Door" policies, but generally demote and keep people down that actually use it.   There are tons of husbands promoting wives(in one case from secretary to assistant director of a department, in one step), based not on skill sets but relationships.  This isn't to mentions sons and daughters and cousins.  Too much inbreeding.

A frustrating place to work if you care about your patients' and practice.

review_title: Clinical Research Coordinator III/ Data Manager in the Clinical Trials office at SKCC
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator III/Data Manager in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
Work location is very convenient in down town Center City Philadelphia.  Easy to commute by local transport. 
Benefits are good.
cons:
I would advise against working here in the Clinical Trials office at SKCC. 

There is a very high turn over rate at the CRO. Full time salaried employees are expected to work 60-80 hours a week without overtime. There is no proper hand over of the work. Expectations about a job are not concrete. Most of the managers dont care about employee feedback. 

The Clinical Trails office has hired so many contractors from a staffing company named Aerotek. I did not come across one employee in the CTO office who has been with the company for more than 2-3 years. Everyone is new, there are no set rules. To much of favoritism going on in this office. Even the doctors have a very high turn over. There are several Multiple Disease Groups (MDG), and the Project Managers for theses groups have no prior managerial experience in a research setting. 

For full time employees, there is a 3 month probation period when you initially join. I had 2 close colleagues who were fired within this period. After their employment was terminated managers went around telling  people that the staff quit, which was not true. Every company has different ways of working, but this was the worst. They tell you one thing during the interview process and later expect something totally different as no one here actually knows what are the expectations from a job, since majority of the staff have been there for less than a year.

review_title: What's not to love when you're in management?
pros: Being on the top heavy side of the hospital definitely is a sweet deal. We get all the pay, and get to make all the decisions without having to actually do any work!! No orientation needed for my job since they created this position (like several others) out of thin air! So I basically get to make up my own job description. In fact, they don't even have my job title listed on this review. Haha. I just listed myself as Nurse Manager because I act like one.  How great is that? I get to meet all sorts of other management types in all the meetings I attend all day while those low level employees have to work understaffed and underpaid. I get to listen to all sorts of complaints without ever having to do anything about them. I just make my staff think I will address something and then never get back to them about it. Working in Center City Philadelphia is really fun too. I get to go on nice lunches all the time. Plenty of opportunities to create new overly complicated and completely unnecessary tasks to add to the staff's workload. Nothing more satisfying then having inexperienced staff alone on a busy floor! You should see how scared they look! Increased my computer skills by sending out dozens of unnecessary emails everyday to clog up the staffs emails so they can't even keep up and will definitely miss something important. Then I can belittle them for not checking their emails enough.  I get to make changes to schedule policies (such as holidays or weekend scheduling) on a whim because it doesn't affect me.
cons: Some staff don't seem to appreciate all the rules I make up but cite that it's a Joint Commission rule. Clinical staff always whining about having to be moved from their own floor to another floor and working up to 4 or 5 different assignments in 1 shift.  Still have too many competent and intelligent staff that just will not give up and quit. They still seem to care too much and expect me to listen to their suggestions to increase patient satisfaction and outcomes and employee morale. Waste of my time since only management gets to make decisions for the department. Sometimes I get worn out from having my "pretend I care about the staffs concerns" face on all day.

pros: TJUH pays well and offers great benefits and there are many different locations to choose from which are all accessible by public transportation
cons: I worked at the Methodist Hosp in S. Philadelphia as a Patient Registrar in the Radiology Dept. where I was bullied and basically treated like dirt!! Serious systemic problems continue to prevail at this location including racial issues as well as age discrimination. It reminded me of the 'mean girl' mentality I had to deal with in grade school and high school with the employees gossiping/whispering to each other behind my back (thinking that I didn't notice) and going out of their way to make me feel like an outcast ( I supposed they knew that I was going to be let go). It was made perfectly clear each day that I wasn't one of their 'favorites'. I was also shocked to hear the medical staff regularly mocking patients, even helpless and sick elderly patients, laughing about their mannerisms and various health issues. Having been a patient of this facility in the past, I found this unprofessional behavior to be appalling and cruel and will never patronize this medical establishment ever again in the future! And just one more word of caution, employees at the Methodist Hospital are being laid off in record numbers, even those with 25+ years of service without ANY notice whatsoever. There was even an administrative level staff member who showed up for work like she did every day for close to 20 years only to be locked out of her office and terminated by being escorted out of the back of the building as if she was some kind of criminal! All of Jefferson's slogans and so called employee well-being programs are nothing but a smokescreen since their HR dept. does not enforce the supposedly "mandatory"  code of conduct policies.
